text: I think I wanted to explore a could of issues here. I'm still trying to relate my current experiences about programming to rfc. In this particular case I was thinking about Lisp and how the code and data are in an ongoing exchange.

text: Which might not be true.  We'll see.

elements.text: Which might not be true.  We'll see.

text: I wouldn't want to isolate one 'biggest problem'.  There's a bunch.

elements.text: I wouldn't want to isolate one 'biggest problem'.  There's a bunch.

text: yes your right :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: yes your right

text: But sure, the high efficiency and thus lack of robustness in many software layers is a big problem.

elements.text: But sure, the high efficiency and thus lack of robustness in many software layers is a big problem.

text: what are the/your next immediate steps of moving rfc forward, how do plan ahead or accept and adopt new collaboration?

text: Yeah, that's what I've built up for debugging so far.

elements.text: Yeah, that's what I've built up for debugging so far.

text: that is how to deal with latency and these related issues on a global scale?

elements.text: that is how to deal with latency and these related issues on a global scale?

text: Not sure what you mean by 'global'.  MFM rejects non-local communication.

elements.text: Not sure what you mean by 'global'.  MFM rejects non-local communication.

text: Exactly because bounded latency does not scale indefinitely.

elements.text: Exactly because bounded latency does not scale indefinitely.

text: Absolutely.  And the question would be why did you want to send that message and could the computation rearrange itself to bring the relevant parts closer together.

text: My goal is to build a compelling enough fragment of a new computational stack -- from hardware to software to demo robust real-time system control -- that people will get excited and carry on the R&D from there.

elements.text: My goal is to build a compelling enough fragment of a new computational stack -- from hardware to software to demo robust real-time system control -- that people will get excited and carry on the R&D from there.

text: Well I want to be cautious about 'self hosting'.  That's one of those things that traditional computing views as nearly a pure virtue, but to me it implies a level of Turing equivalence/universality that leads to a vast decrease in behavioral predictability at that level.

elements.text: Well I want to be cautious about 'self hosting'.  That's one of those things that traditional computing views as nearly a pure virtue, but to me it implies a level of Turing equivalence/universality that leads to a vast decrease in behavioral predictability at that level.

text: One of the robust-first slogans is: *Delay universality*

text: So I might argue it would be better to go the other way: Get to the point where T2 (or really, T3, T4, something) tiles would be only one-time programmable or even not programmable at all.

elements.text: So I might argue it would be better to go the other way: Get to the point where T2 (or really, T3, T4, something) tiles would be only one-time programmable or even not programmable at all.

text: Yes ULAM is a C-like language for working with rfc. It’s not that much different than C++ in how it treats code. There’s also a newer language for defining spatial rewrite rules in ascii while allowing to bind complex predicates to ascii. This is way more in line with rfc (spatial and local computation etc).

elements.text: Yes ULAM is a C-like language for working with rfc. It’s not that much different than C++ in how it treats code. There’s also a newer language for defining spatial rewrite rules in ascii while allowing to bind complex predicates to ascii. This is way more in line with rfc (spatial and local computation etc).
